L2_gloss:
the Central Kurdish question mark
‏چۆنیت؟‎‎ ― çonît? ― How are you?
Adam (first man in the Bible and Qur’an)
freedom (the lack of a specific constraint)
pharmacy (a place where prescription drugs are dispensed)
A male given name from Arabic, equivalent to English
The second letter of the Kurdo-Arabic alphabet. Its name is با‎ (ba) and it has the sound of English b. It is preceded by ا‎ (a) and followed by پ‎ (pi). Equivalent to b in the Kurdo-Latin alphabet.
to, ‏ئەرزی بە پاشا کرد لە شتێک‎‎Erzî be paşa kird le
A suffix forming the comparative degree of an adjective.
thick, viscous, syrupy (of liquid), strong (of tea,
combines with several verbs, usually as “off” or “down”
justice (state of being just or fair)
tree, wood (substance, timber), stick, staff, rod
pharmacy (a place where prescription drugs are dispensed)
to know (be certain or sure about (something))

(indefinite, in the singular) something, anything
‏ئەرزی بە پاشا کرد لە شتێک‎‎Erzî be paşa kird le şitêkHe petitioned the king for something
gall nut, oak apple, oak gall, gall apple, Aleppo gall
fashion (current (constantly changing) trend, favored for frivolous rather than practical, logical, or intellectual reasons)
to know, to be acquainted with, to recognize
The third letter of the Kurdo-Arabic alphabet. Its name is پا‎ (pa) and it has the sound of English P. It is preceded by ب‎ (bi) and followed by ت‎ (ti).
occupation (activity or task with which one occupies oneself)

form of "بە‎ (be)" used with clitic pronouns
‏بەڵێنم پێت دا‎ ― bellênim pêt da ― I promised you
‏هیچت پێ ناکرێ‎ ― hîçit pê nakirê ― nothing can be done by you
knife (utensil or tool designed for cutting)
(interrogative) how much, how many, to what extent
A letter of the Kurdish-Arabic alphabet, pronounced [v]
caravan (a convoy or procession of travelers, their vehicles and cargo, and any pack animals)
Kurd (a member of the people inhabiting Kurdistan)
partridge (a bird of the genera Perdix or Alectoris)
to take, to seize, to catch, to capture, to pinch

all, every, whole, entire, all of
Used to express sorrow, regret, compassion or grief.
